member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer
member.summary: Makes a route network analysis layer and sets its analysis properties. A route analysis layer is useful for determining the best route between a set of network locations based on a specified network cost.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The network dataset on which the route analysis will be performed. (In, Required)
Name of the route network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)
The cost attribute to be used as impedance in the analysis. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.in_network_dataset
member.summary: The network dataset on which the route analysis will be performed. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.out_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: Name of the route network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.impedance_attribute
member.summary: The cost attribute to be used as impedance in the analysis. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.find_best_order
member.summary: Reorder Stops to Find Optimal Route (in, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.ordering_type
member.summary: Specifies the ordering of stops when FIND_BEST_ORDER is used. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.time_windows
member.summary: Specifies whether time windows will be used at the stops. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.accumulate_attribute_name
member.summary: A list of cost attributes to be accumulated during analysis. These accumulation attributes are purely for reference; the solver only uses the cost attribute specified by the Impedance Attribute parameter to calculate the route. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.UTurn_policy
member.summary:
The U-Turn policy at junctions. Allowing U-turns implies the solver can turn around at a junction and double back on the same street.
Given that junctions represent street intersections and dead ends, different vehicles may be able to turn around at some junctions but not at others—it depends on whether the junction represents an intersection or dead end. To accommodate this, the U-turn policy parameter is implicitly specified by how many edges connect to the junction, which is known as junction valency. The acceptable values for this parameter are listed below; each is followed by a description of its meaning in terms of junction valency. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.restriction_attribute_name
member.summary: A list of restriction attributes to apply during the analysis. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.hierarchy
member.summary: The parameter is not used if a hierarchy attribute is not defined on the network dataset used to perform the analysis. In such cases, use "#" as the parameter value. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.hierarchy_settings
member.summary: Prior to version 10, this parameter allowed you to change the hierarchy ranges for your analysis from the default hierarchy ranges established in the network dataset. At version 10, this parameter is no longer supported and should be specified as an empty string. If you want to change the hierarchy ranges for your analysis, update the default hierarchy ranges in the network dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.output_path_shape
member.summary: Specifies the shape type for the route features that are output by the analysis. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.start_date_time
member.summary: Specifies a start date and time for the route. Route start time is typically used to find routes based on the impedance attribute that varies with the time of the day. For example, a start time of 7 a.m. could be used to find a route that considers the rush hour traffic. The default value for this parameter is 8:00 a.m. A date and time can be specified as 10/21/05 10:30 AM. If the route spans multiple days and only the start time is specified, the current date is used. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.output_layer
member.summary: Network Analyst Layer (out, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.summary: The name of this tool's toolbox.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.ToolName
member.summary: The name of this tool.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.Alias
member.summary: The alias for this tool's toolbox.

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeRouteLayer.ParameterInfo
member.summary: The parameters used by this tool. For internal use only.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations
member.summary: Adds network analysis objects to a network analysis layer. The objects are added to specific sublayers such as Stops and Barriers. Objects are input as features or records.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The network analysis layer to which the network analysis objects will be added. (In, Required)
The sublayer of the network analysis layer to which the network analysis objects will be added. (In, Required)
The feature class or table that will be the source for the new network analysis objects. (In, Required)
Sets the values for the properties of the network analysis objects. Properties can be set to a constant or mapped to a field from the input feature class or table. (In, Required)

The search tolerance for locating the input features on the network. Features that are outside the search tolerance are left unlocated. The parameter includes a value and units for the tolerance. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.in_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: The network analysis layer to which the network analysis objects will be added. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.sub_layer
member.summary: The sublayer of the network analysis layer to which the network analysis objects will be added. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.in_table
member.summary: The feature class or table that will be the source for the new network analysis objects. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.field_mappings
member.summary: Sets the values for the properties of the network analysis objects. Properties can be set to a constant or mapped to a field from the input feature class or table. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.search_tolerance
member.summary: The search tolerance for locating the input features on the network. Features that are outside the search tolerance are left unlocated. The parameter includes a value and units for the tolerance. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.sort_field
member.summary: The field on which the network analysis objects are sorted as they are added to the network analysis layer. The default is the ObjectID field on the input feature class or the table. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.search_criteria
member.summary: Specifies which sources in the network dataset will be searched when finding locations and what portions of geometry (also known as snap types) will be used. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.match_type
member.summary: Specifies how the network locations will be matched. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.append
member.summary: Specifies whether to append new network analysis objects to existing objects. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.snap_to_position_along_network
member.summary: Specifies whether to snap the network locations along the network dataset or at some specified offset from the network dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.snap_offset
member.summary: When snapping a point to the network, you can apply an offset distance. An offset distance of zero means the point will be coincident with the network feature (typically, a line). To offset the point from the network feature, enter an offset distance. The offset is in relation to the original point location; that is, if the original point was on the left side, its new location will be offset to the left. If it was originally on the right side, its new location will be offset to the right. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.exclude_restricted_elements
member.summary: Specifies whether restricted network elements will be excluded. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.search_query
member.summary: A query that will restrict the search to a subset of the features within a source feature class. This is useful if you don't want to find features that may be unsuited for a network location. For example, if you are loading centroids of polygons and don't want to locate on local roads, you can define a query that searches for major roads only. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.AddLocations.output_layer
member.summary: Network Analyst Layer (out, Optional)

member.summary: The directory of this tool's toolbox.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions
member.summary: Generates turn-by-turn directions from a network analysis layer with routes. The directions can be written to a file in text, XML, or HTML format. If you provide an appropriate stylesheet, the directions can be written to any other file format.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: Network analysis layer for which directions will be generated. Directions can be generated only for route, closest facility, and vehicle routing problem network analysis layers. (In, Required)
The format of the output directions file. This parameter is ignored if the stylesheet parameter has a value. (In, Required)
If you provide a stylesheet in the stylesheet parameter, make sure the file suffix for out_directions_file matches the file type your stylesheet produces. (Out, Required)

Specifies the linear units in which the length information will be reported in the directions file. For example, even though your impedance was in meters, you can show directions in miles. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.in_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: Network analysis layer for which directions will be generated. Directions can be generated only for route, closest facility, and vehicle routing problem network analysis layers. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.file_type
member.summary: The format of the output directions file. This parameter is ignored if the stylesheet parameter has a value. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.out_directions_file
member.summary: If you provide a stylesheet in the stylesheet parameter, make sure the file suffix for out_directions_file matches the file type your stylesheet produces. (Out, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.report_units
member.summary: Specifies the linear units in which the length information will be reported in the directions file. For example, even though your impedance was in meters, you can show directions in miles. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.report_time
member.summary: Report Travel Time (in, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.time_attribute
member.summary: The time-based cost attribute to provide travel times in the directions. The cost attribute must exist on the network dataset used by the input network analysis layer. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.language
member.summary: Choose a language in which to generate driving directions. The languages that are shown in the drop-down list depend on which ArcGIS language packs are installed on your computer. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.style_name
member.summary: Choose the name of the formatting style for the directions. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.Directions.stylesheet
member.summary: The stylesheet for generating a formatted output file type (such as a PDF, Word, or HTML file). The suffix of the file in the output directions file parameter should match the file type that the stylesheet generates. member.summary: Network Analyst Layer (out, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.BuildNetwork
member.summary: Reconstructs the network connectivity and attribute information of a network dataset. The network dataset must be rebuilt after edits are made to the attributes or the features of a participating source feature class. After the source features are edited, the tool establishes the network connectivity only in the areas that have been edited to speed up the build process; however, when the network attributes are edited, the entire extent of the network dataset is rebuilt. This may be a slow operation on a large network dataset.

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer
member.summary: Makes a vehicle routing problem (VRP) network analysis layer and sets its analysis properties. A vehicle routing problem analysis layer is useful for optimizing a set of routes using a fleet of vehicles.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The network dataset on which the vehicle routing problem analysis will be performed. The network dataset must have a time based cost attribute since the VRP solver minimizes time. (In, Required)
Name of the vehicle routing problem network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)

The time cost attribute used to define the traversal time along the elements of the network. The time cost attribute is required, since the vehicle routing problem solver minimizes time. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.in_network_dataset
member.summary: The network dataset on which the vehicle routing problem analysis will be performed. The network dataset must have a time based cost attribute since the VRP solver minimizes time. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.out_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: Name of the vehicle routing problem network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.time_impedance
member.summary: The time cost attribute used to define the traversal time along the elements of the network. The time cost attribute is required, since the vehicle routing problem solver minimizes time. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.distance_impedance
member.summary: The distance cost attribute used to define the length along the elements of the network. The distance cost attribute is optional. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.time_units
member.summary: The time units used by the temporal fields of the analysis layer's sublayers and tables (network analysis classes). This does not have to be the same as the units of the time cost attribute. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.distance_units
member.summary: The distance units used by distance fields of the analysis layer's sublayers and tables (network analysis classes). This does not have to be the same as the units of the optional distance cost attribute. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.default_date
member.summary: The implied date for time field values that don't have a date specified with the time. If a time field for an order object, such as TimeWindowStart1, has a time-only value, the date is assumed to be the default date. For example, if an order has a TimeWindowStart1 value of 9:00 AM and the default date is March 6, 2013, then the entire time value for the field is 9:00 A.M., March 6, 2013. The default date has no effect on time field values that already have a date. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.capacity_count
member.summary: The number of capacity constraint dimensions required to describe the relevant limits of the vehicles. In an order delivery case, each vehicle may have a limited amount of weight and volume it can carry at one time based on physical and legal limitations. In this case, if you track the weight and volume on the orders, you can use these two capacities to prevent the vehicles from getting overloaded. The capacity count for this scenario is two (weight and volume). Depending on the problem, you may need to track different types or amounts of capacities. The capacities entered into the capacity fields (DeliveryQuantities and PickupQuantities for the Orders class and Capacities for the Routes class) are space-delimited strings of numbers, which can hold up to the number of values specified in Capacity Count. Each capacity dimension should appear in the same positional order for all capacity field values in the same VRP analysis layer. The capacities themselves are unnamed, so to avoid accidentally transposing capacity dimensions, ensure that the space-delimited capacity lists are always entered in the same order for all capacity field values. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.time_window_factor
member.summary: This parameter allows you to rate the importance of honoring time windows without causing violations. A time window violation occurs when a route arrives at an order, depot, or break after a time window has closed. The violation is the interval between the end of the time window and the arrival time of a route. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.excess_transit_factor
member.summary: This parameter allows you to rate the importance of reducing excess transit time. Excess transit time is the amount of time exceeding the time required to travel directly between the paired orders. The excess time results from breaks or travel to other orders or depots between visits to the paired orders. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.UTurn_policy
member.summary:
The U-Turn policy at junctions. Allowing U-turns implies the solver can turn around at a junction and double back on the same street.
Given that junctions represent street intersections and dead ends, different vehicles may be able to turn around at some junctions but not at others—it depends on whether the junction represents an intersection or dead end. To accommodate this, the U-turn policy parameter is implicitly specified by how many edges connect to the junction, which is known as junction valency. The acceptable values for this parameter are listed below; each is followed by a description of its meaning in terms of junction valency. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.restriction_attribute_name
member.summary: A list of restriction attributes to apply during the analysis. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.hierarchy
member.summary: The parameter is not used if a hierarchy attribute is not defined on the network dataset used to perform the analysis. In such cases, use "#" as the parameter value. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeVehicleRoutingProblemLayer.hierarchy_settings
member.summary: Prior to version 10, this parameter allowed you to change the hierarchy ranges for your analysis from the default hierarchy ranges established in the network dataset. At version 10, this parameter is no longer supported and should be specified as an empty string. If you want to change the hierarchy ranges for your analysis, update the default hierarchy ranges in the network dataset. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer
member.summary: Makes a location-allocation network analysis layer and sets its analysis properties. A location-allocation analysis layer is useful for choosing a given number of facilities from a set of potential locations such that a demand will be allocated to facilities in an optimal and efficient manner.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.#ctor(System.Object,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The network dataset on which the location-allocation analysis will be performed. (In, Required)
Name of the location-allocation network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)
The cost attribute to be used as impedance in the analysis. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.in_network_dataset
member.summary: The network dataset on which the location-allocation analysis will be performed. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.out_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: Name of the location-allocation network analysis layer to create. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.impedance_attribute
member.summary: The cost attribute to be used as impedance in the analysis. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.loc_alloc_from_to
member.summary: Specifies the direction of travel between facilities and demand points when calculating the network costs. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.loc_alloc_problem_type
member.summary: The problem type that will be solved. The choice of the problem type depends on the kind of facility being located. Different kinds of facilities have different priorities and constraints. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.number_facilities_to_find
member.summary: Specifies the number of facilities that the solver should locate. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.impedance_cutoff
member.summary: Impedance Cutoff specifies the maximum impedance at which a demand point can be allocated to a facility. The maximum impedance is measured by the least-cost path along the network. If a demand point is outside the cutoff, it is left unallocated. This property might be used to model the maximum distance that people are willing to travel to visit your stores or the maximum time that is permitted for a fire department to reach anyone in the community. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.impedance_transformation
member.summary: This sets the equation for transforming the network cost between facilities and demand points. This property, coupled with the Impedance Parameter, specifies how severely the network impedance between facilities and demand points influences the solver's choice of facilities. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.impedance_parameter
member.summary: Provides a parameter value to the equations specified in the Impedance transformation parameter. The parameter value is ignored when the impedance transformation is of type LINEAR. For POWER and EXPONENTIAL impedance transformations, the value should be nonzero. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.target_market_share
member.summary: Specifies the target market share in percentage to solve for when the Location-Allocation Problem Type parameter is set to TARGET_MARKET_SHARE . It is the percentage of the total demand weight that you want your solution facilities to capture. The solver chooses the minimum number of facilities required to capture the target market share specified by this numeric value. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.MakeLocationAllocationLayer.accumulate_attribute_name
member.summary: A list of cost attributes to be accumulated during analysis. These accumulation attributes are purely for reference; the solver only uses the cost attribute specified by the Impedance Attribute parameter to calculate the route. (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.DissolveNetwork
member.summary: Creates a network dataset that minimizes the number of line features required to correctly model the input network dataset. The more efficient output network dataset reduces the time required to solve analyses, draw results, and generate driving directions. This tool outputs a new network dataset and source feature classes; the input network dataset and its source features remain unchanged.

member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The network dataset to be dissolved. (In, Required)

The geodatabase workspace in which to create the dissolved network dataset. The workspace must be an ArcGIS 10 geodatabase or later, and it must be a different geodatabase than the one where the input network dataset resides. (In, Required)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem
member.summary: Creates a vehicle routing problem (VRP) network analysis layer, sets the analysis properties, and solves the analysis, which is ideal for setting up a VRP web service. A vehicle routing problem analysis layer finds the best routes for a fleet of vehicles.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: The orders that the routes of the VRP analysis should visit. An order can represent a delivery (for example, furniture delivery), a pickup (such as an airport shuttle bus picking up a passenger), or some type of service or inspection (a tree trimming job or building inspection, for instance). (In, Required)

param.name: depots
param.summary: A depot is a location that a vehicle departs from at the beginning of the workday and returns to at the end of the workday. Vehicles are loaded (for deliveries) or unloaded (for pickups) at depots at the start of the route. In some cases, a depot can also act as a renewal location, whereby the vehicle can unload or reload and continue performing deliveries and pickups. A depot has open and close times, as specified by a hard time window. Vehicles can't arrive at a depot outside of this time window. (In, Required)

param.name: routes
param.summary: The routes that are available for the given vehicle routing problem. A route specifies vehicle and driver characteristics; after solving, it also represents the path between depots and orders. (In, Required)

member.param: The rest periods, or breaks, for the routes in a given vehicle routing problem. A break is associated with exactly one route, and it can be taken after completing an order, while en route to an order, or prior to servicing an order. It has a start time and a duration, for which the driver may or may not be paid. There are three options for establishing when a break begins: using a time window, a maximum travel time, or a maximum work time. (In, Required)

param.name: time_units
param.summary: Specifies the time units for all time-based field values in the analysis. (In, Required)

member.param: Specifies the distance units for all distance-based field values in the analysis. (In, Required)

param.name: network_dataset
param.summary: The network dataset on which the vehicle routing problem analysis will be performed. The network dataset must have a time-based cost attribute, since the VRP solver minimizes time. (In, Required)

param.name: output_workspace_location
param.summary: The file geodatabase or in-memory workspace in which the output feature classes will be created. This workspace must already exist. The default output workspace is in memory. (In, Required)

param.name: output_unassigned_stops_name
param.summary: The name of the output feature class that will contain any unreachable depots or unassigned orders. (In, Required)

param.name: output_stops_name
param.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain the stops visited by routes. This feature class includes stops at depots, orders, and breaks. (In, Required)

param.name: output_routes_name
param.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain the routes of the analysis. (In, Required)

param.name: output_directions_name
param.summary:
The name of the feature class that will contain the directions for the routes.
(In, Required)

member.summary:
The U-Turn policy at junctions. Allowing U-turns implies the solver can turn around at a junction and double back on the same street.
Given that junctions represent street intersections and dead ends, different vehicles may be able to turn around at some junctions but not at others—it depends on whether the junction represents an intersection or dead end. To accommodate this, the U-turn policy parameter is implicitly specified by how many edges connect to the junction, which is known as junction valency. The acceptable values for this parameter are listed below; each is followed by a description of its meaning in terms of junction valency. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.time_window_factor
member.summary: Specifies the importance of honoring time windows. There are three options, which are listed and described below. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.spatially_cluster_routes
member.summary: Specifies whether the solver will automatically create dynamic seed points. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.route_zones
member.summary: Delineates work territories for given routes. A route zone is a polygon feature and is used to constrain routes to servicing only those orders that fall within or near the specified area. The following are examples of when route zones may be useful: Some of your employees don't have the required permits to perform work in certain states or communities. You can create a hard route zone so they only visit orders in areas where they meet the requirements.One of your vehicles breaks down frequently, so you want to minimize response time by having it only visit orders that are close to your maintenance garage. You can create a soft or hard route zone to keep the vehicle nearby. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.route_renewals
member.summary: Specifies the intermediate depots that routes can visit to reload or unload the cargo they are delivering or picking up. Specifically, a route renewal links a route to a depot. The relationship indicates that the route can renew (reload or unload while en route) at the associated depot. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.order_pairs
member.summary: Pairs pick up and deliver orders so they are serviced by the same route. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.excess_transit_factor
member.summary:
Specifies the importance of reducing excess transit time of order pairs. Excess transit time is the amount of time exceeding the time required to travel directly between the paired orders. Excess time can be caused by driver breaks or travel to intermediate orders and depots.
(In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.point_barriers
member.summary: Specifies point barriers, which are split into two types: restriction and added cost point barriers. They temporarily restrict traversal across or add impedance to points on the network. The point barriers are defined by a feature set, and the attribute values you specify for the point features determine whether they are restriction or added cost barriers. The fields in the attribute table are listed and described below. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.line_barriers
member.summary: Specifies line barriers, which temporarily restrict traversal across them. The line barriers are defined by a feature set. The fields in the attribute table are listed and described below. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.polygon_barriers
member.summary: Specifies polygon barriers, which are split into two types: restriction and scaled cost polygon barriers. They temporarily restrict traversal or scale impedance on the parts of the network they cover. The polygon barriers are defined by a feature set, and the attribute values you specify for the polygon features determine whether they are restriction or scaled cost barriers. The fields in the attribute table are listed and described below. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.time_attribute
member.summary: The network cost attribute to use when determining the travel time of network elements. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.distance_attribute
member.summary:
The network cost attribute to use when determining the distance of network elements.
(In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.use_hierarchy_in_analysis
member.summary: The parameter is not used if a hierarchy attribute is not defined on the network dataset used to perform the analysis. In such cases, use "#" as the parameter value. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.restrictions
member.summary: Indicates which network restriction attributes are respected during solve time. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.attribute_parameter_values
member.summary: Specifies the parameter values for network attributes that have parameters. The record set has two columns that work together to uniquely identify parameters and another column that specifies the parameter value. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.maximum_snap_tolerance
member.summary: The maximum snap tolerance is the furthest distance that Network Analyst searches when locating or relocating a point onto the network. The search looks for suitable edges or junctions and snaps the point to the nearest one. If a suitable location isn't found within the maximum snap tolerance, the object is marked as unlocated. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.exclude_restricted_portions_of_the_network
member.summary: Specifies where network locations are placed. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.feature_locator_where_clause
member.summary: An SQL expression used to select a subset of source features that limits on which network elements orders and depots can be located. For example, to ensure orders and depots are not located on limited-access highways, write an SQL expression that excludes those source features. Note that the other network analysis objects, such as barriers, ignore the feature locator WHERE clause when loading. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.populate_route_lines
member.summary: Specifies whether lines that show the true shape of the routes will be generated. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.route_line_simplification_tolerance
member.summary: The simplification distance of the route geometry. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.populate_directions
member.summary:
Specifies whether driving directions will be generated.
(In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.directions_language
member.summary: The language in which driving directions will be generated. The languages available in the drop-down list depend on which ArcGIS language packs are installed on your computer. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.directions_style_name
member.summary: Specifies the formatting style of directions. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.save_output_layer
member.summary: Specifies whether the output includes a network analysis layer of the results. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.service_capabilities
member.summary: Specifies the maximum amount of computer processing that occurs when running this tool as a geoprocessing service. You may want to do this for one of two reasons: to avoid letting your server solve problems that require more resources or processing time than you want to allow, or to create multiple services with different VRP capabilities to support a business model. For example, if you have a tiered-service business model, you may want to provide a free VRP service that supports a maximum of five routes per solve and another service that is fee-based and supports more than five routes per solve. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.ignore_invalid_order_locations
member.summary: Specifies whether invalid orders will be ignored when solving the vehicle routing problem. (In, Optional)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.SolveVehicleRoutingProblem.travel_mode
member.summary: Choose the mode of transportation for the analysis. CUSTOM is always a choice. For other travel mode names to appear, they must be present in the network dataset specified in the Network_Dataset parameter. (The arcpy.na.GetTravelModes function provides a dictionary of the travel mode objects configured on a network dataset, and the name property returns the name of a travel mode object.) (In, Optional)

member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.UpdateTrafficData
member.summary: Downloads live traffic data from a web service and stores it in a dynamic traffic format (DTF) file, which is a file that network datasets can read for live-traffic analysis and display.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.UpdateTrafficData.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.
member.param: Choose the name of your traffic data provider and the region. (In, Required)

param.name: user_name
param.summary: The user name authorized by the data provider to download traffic data. The tool fails to execute if the user name cannot be authenticated by the data provider. (In, Required)

param.name: password
param.summary: The password provided by the data provider to download traffic data. The tool fails to execute if the password cannot be authenticated by the data provider. (In, Required)

param.name: regions
param.summary: Enter the regions for which you want to download traffic data. To download all available regions, enter "#". (In, Required)

param.name: traffic_data_output_folder
param.summary: The folder in which the DTF file will be created. If the folder is empty, the tool creates a TrafficIndex.xml file along with the DTF file. For subsequent tool runs, the tool updates TrafficIndex.xml and creates a DTF file. (In, Required)

param.name: expected_update_interval
param.summary: The time interval in minutes after which the downloaded traffic data is no longer up-to-date, and the data provider makes available refreshed data. After this interval has elapsed, it is recommended that you rerun the tool and download the latest data. (In, Required)

param.name: prediction_cutoff
param.summary: The time interval (in minutes) for which the predictive traffic data is processed by the tool. Data providers may supply predictive data for the next 24 hours, week, or other time period. The time-span value for this parameter is used to limit the amount of predictive traffic data that is processed by the tool to speed up tool execution. For example, if your traffic provider has a prediction depth of 24 hours, but you need only one hour of prediction depth, you can save time by specifying 60 here. (In, Required)

member.param: Compress Data (in)

member.summary: Choose the name of your traffic data provider and the region. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.UpdateTrafficData.user_name

member.summary: The time interval (in minutes) for which the traffic files (that is, the DTF files) will be kept in the traffic data output folder. This parameter facilitates deleting traffic files that are no longer required. When the tool is rerun, any traffic data files that are older than the maximum file age are deleted automatically. member.name: T:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures
member.summary: Creates two feature classes and a table, which together contain information about the edges, junctions, and turns that are traversed while solving a network analysis layer.

member.name: M:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.#ctor(System.Object,System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Constructor that takes all required parameters for geoprocessor execution.

param.name: input_network_analysis_layer
param.summary: The network analysis layer from which traversed source features will be copied. If the network analysis layer does not have a valid result, the layer will be solved to produce one. (In, Required)

param.name: output_location
param.summary: The workspace where the output table and two feature classes will be saved. (In, Required)

param.name: edge_feature_class_name
param.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain information about the traversed edge source features. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any edge features, an empty feature class is created. (In, Required)

param.name: junction_feature_class_name
param.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain information about the traversed junction source features, including system junctions and relevant points from the input network analysis layer. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any junctions, an empty feature class is created. (In, Required)

param.name: turn_table_name
param.summary: The name of the table that will contain information about the traversed global turns and turn features that scale cost for the underlying edges. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any turns, an empty table is created. Since restricted turns are never traversed, they are never included in the output. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.input_network_analysis_layer
member.summary: The network analysis layer from which traversed source features will be copied. If the network analysis layer does not have a valid result, the layer will be solved to produce one. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.output_location
member.summary: The workspace where the output table and two feature classes will be saved. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.edge_feature_class_name
member.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain information about the traversed edge source features. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any edge features, an empty feature class is created. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.junction_feature_class_name
member.summary: The name of the feature class that will contain information about the traversed junction source features, including system junctions and relevant points from the input network analysis layer. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any junctions, an empty feature class is created. (In, Required)

member.name: P:ESRI.ArcGIS.NetworkAnalystTools.CopyTraversedSourceFeatures.turn_table_name
member.summary: The name of the table that will contain information about the traversed global turns and turn features that scale cost for the underlying edges. If the solved network analysis layer doesn't traverse any turns, an empty table is created. Since restricted turns are never traversed, they are never included in the output. (In, Required)
